title: how colour blind people see world
story: Three million people living in the UK are colour blind - the vast majority of those are men.One in  men is affected, whereas for women its one in .There are dferent types of colour blindness, depending on how the person processes light.Eyecare provider Lenstore and charity Colour Blindness Awareness UK to reveal what le is like for someone with the deficiency.Tritanopia is a rare form and is the inability to process blue light.People with this version confuse light blues with greys, dark purples with black, mid-greens with blues and oranges with reds.Protanopia is the inability to see red light - mixing red with green and green with blue.And lastly, deuteranopia is when people are unable to process green light.

title: brexit could radicalising far right
story: NewsBrexit could be radicalising the far-right suggests UKs top counter-terror copNeil Basu warned a spike in hate crime after the EU referendum "never really receded" - and theres "always a possibility people are being radicalised by the febrile atmosphere"ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNeil Basu, the countrys top counter-terror cop, sounded the alarm "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe atmosphere around Brexit could be radicalising far-right activists, the countrys top counter-terrorism policeman has suggested. Neil Basu warned officers have been working very hard to ensure there is not a far-right drt into extreme right-wing terrorism. The Met Police Assistant Commissioner said of  terror plots foiled in Britain since ,  were Islamist but four were far-right. He told the BBC: We saw a spike in hate crime after the referendum, thats never really receded. So theres always a possibility people are being radicalised by the kind of febrile atmosphere weve got at the moment.   We want people to report anything that we think is going to lead to violent confrontation. People need to calm down and understand that we are paying very close attention to that and we will stop it wherever we see it. It comes after Mr Basu said yesterday he finds the prospect of a no-deal Brexit on March  incredibly concerning. The senior officer said losing access to shared data and intelligence systems would put the UK and Europe in a very bad place. He said yesterday: For counter-terrorism we have a lot of bilateral relationships, it is a devolved power for countries, it is not an EU power, so we are confident that my counterparts in those  countries want to exchange information with us and we are working very hard to make sure we put that in place.   But nevertheless, to leave without ... being able to exchange data or biometrics on people who might be criminals or terrorists would be a very bad place for this country, and for Europe, to be. Mr Basu said there was a central team working on contingency plans, while counter-terrorism police liaison officers were embedded in embassies and agencies in Europe. He said: They are working very hard with their counterparts to understand how we copethere is a no-deal Brexit, but as I said, a no-deal Brexit for operational security would be a very bad thing. Mr Basu said there was no intelligence pointing to an increased level of attacks after Brexit, but he was concerned about a potential rise in hate crime. He said: Whats most concerning me about Brexit is its potential to ide communities and set communities against each other. So what we saw after the referendumwas a rise in hate crime, and a rise in far-right rhetoric, and we have seen the growth of organisations like National Action, and what I want to make absolutely clear is that we are concentrating very heavily on making sure that doesnt get a foothold in this country.  Im really proud to be a UK citizen in a country that is largely tolerant, and we havent seen an explosion in that threat. What Im concerned about is the creeping rise of that threat, andwe arent clear that we are combating that threat then thats my concern. Mr Basu was speaking yesterday at the launch of a major cinema advert campaign to increase awareness of suspicious activity and encourage people to report it to police. The -second film shows a series of scenarios, such as a man stockpiling hazardous material and another buying weapons, before rewinding and zooming in on the danger. In  and , around a fth of the information passed to police from the public had a signicant role in thwarting attacks, he said. Four far-right extremist plots and  Islamist terror plots were foiled in the last two years.

title: brexit george osborne tells uk
story: NewsBrexit: George Osborne tells the UK No Deal could put a bullet in your head"The gun is held to the British economy’s head," the Tory ex-Chancellor declaredShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video george-osborne-declares-no-deal-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNo Deal Brexit could put a bullet in your head, Tory George Osborne has told the UK. The former Chancellor made the violent warning as he described leaving without agreement as Russian Roulette. Speaking from a summit of the worlds business elite in Davos, Mr Osborne predicted the  March leaving date will be delayed. Butit isnt, the ardent pro-Remain millionaire said, there would be dire consequences. The gun is held to the British economy’s head, he told the BBC.   Russian roulette is a game which obviously you should never play, in which there’s a one-in-six chance that the bullet goes into your head. If you start pretending we might leave without a deal, then that might become a reality. And I think its interesting that my successor Philip Hammond has sensibly told British businesses leaders thats not a possibility. We now need to hear it from the British Prime Minister. It is the second time Mr Osborne has made headlines for his colourful and violent use of language.   After becoming a newspaper editor, he sparked fury by telling pals he wouldnt rest until Theresa May was chopped up in bags in my freezer. Mr Osborne spoke as Labour looked set to back a Parliamentary move that could delay Brexit and block No Deal. He added: I think at the moment delay looks like the most likely option because at least that gives some space to explore whether theres an alternative deal on the table. I doubt there is, but thats worth exploring, or whether we need to resolve this through a referendum.

title: grenfell two post manchester tower
story: NewsGrenfell two is in the post as Manchester tower block with danger cladding revealedLabours Emma Dent Coad accused the minister of treating the issue like some sort of theoretical exerciseShareByNick Sommerlad:,  JAN NewsGrenfell two is in the post, said MP Emma Dent Coad "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGovernment ministers were warned “Grenfell two is in the post” after the Mirror revealed a tower block in Manchester is shycovered in combustible cladding. Labour’s Emma Dent Coad, the local MP to Grenfell Tower, made the warning after the Mirror found the X Eastbank block failed a fire-spread test after just  minutes. Housing Minister Kit Malthouse, responding to an urgent Commons question on the issue, said he was “satisfied everybody who is resident of that block at the moment is safe”. But Ms Dent Coad accused the minister of treating the issue “like some sort of theoretical exercise”.   She said: “Just saying that the minister is satisfied is not really enough. Nothing has yet changed, the Government is ignoring warnings, our constituents are going to bed afraid, current measures are not working. “As one of the Grenfell survivors said, ‘Grenfell two is in the post’. “How many more must die before the Government takes positive action to keep people safe in their beds ”   Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey added: “It’s shocking the Government’s own figures show there were  high-rise blocks with the same Grenfell-style cladding and  are yet to have this removed. “It’s shocking that the minister knows every one of these blocks, but won’t name the landlords and won’t tell the residents.” Eighteen months after Britain’s worst fire in a century, Government figures show just five out of  privately owned blocks have had their Grenfell-style cladding removed.  Defending the Government’s response to the tragedy in West London, which killed  people, as “immediate and wide-ranging”, Mr Malthouse said “signicant resource and effort has been injected into removing this cladding”. Yesterday, the Mirror revealed images from test footage showing flames spreading up a replica wall of cladding within minutes. Residents at the X had not been told of the shocking test for seven weeks until approached by the Mirror.

title: no deal brexit set blocked
story: NewsNo Deal Brexit set to be BLOCKED as Labour gears up to help delay March  dateTwo of Jeremy Corbyns closest allies now indicate hell back a move that would delay the  March date of Brexit - and stop the UK leaving with no dealShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsJeremy Corbyn is seriously considering the move "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Brexit looks more likely than ever to be delayed after Labour revealed it is gearing up to inflict defeat on Theresa May. Two top allies of Jeremy Corbyn indicated the party will join with Tory rebels to prevent a No Deal Brexit on March . Their bid is due for a vote next Tuesday night - andLabour formally backs it, it should have more than enough support to pass. The amendment led by Labours Yvette Cooper and Tory Nick Boles would force the Prime Minister to request a delay to Brexitthere is still no deal by February . There are still some blockages. The amendment must still be selected by the Speaker. A delay could still be preventedthe EU doesnt agree, and Tory ministers continue to insist No Deal Brexit is the legal default. But reports out of Brussels have suggested EU chiefs are open to delaying Brexit. Furious Tory Cabinet minister Liam Fox today claimed the amendment would not actually have the power to delay Brexit - and said doing so would be worse than leaving with no deal. But Tory former Chancellor George Osborne said no deal would be a bullet in your head, adding: At the moment delay looks the most likely option.   And Pascal Cagni, French ambassador for international investment, said his prediction is now that the  March date of Brexit will be postponed.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said it was highly likely Labour will back the delay Brexit amendment. He told BBC Newsnight: Yvette Cooper has put an amendment down, which I think is sensible.  It says to the Government youve run down the clock so much, it looks as thoughyou cant get a deal by February ... the Government will then have to bring forward proposals to extend that. So I think its increasingly likely already that well have to take that option because the Government has run the clock down.  MrMcDonnellsaid Labour had to go through its own party processes to determine whether they would back it, but added: Its highly likely but well go through our normal process of consultation with our members.Shadow Cabinet Office Minister Jon Trickett went further, saying: Labour wants to stop a no-deal Brexit because of the damage it will do. If a resolution comes forward, in principle yes we can back it.A source close to Jeremy Corbyn confirmed he was seriously considering the amendment. Labour is expected to take a formal decision on whether it will whip MPs next week.  Furious Brexiteer Cabinet minister Liam Fox said the amendment would change the constitution without us having a proper debate.He told Sky News: This would make parliament both the initiator and the judge of the law. Thats a fundamental change.Dr Fox admitted today that some world leaders dont believe no deal will happen. He said he was in Davos - the summit of the elite in Switzerland - to convince other countries that no deal is a genuine possibility.DrFoxtold BBC Radio s Today programme that there are many who talk about delaying Brexit when what they really mean is not having Brexit at all, saying that would be the worst outcome. I think the most calamitous outcome would be for Parliament, having promised to respect the result of the referendum, to turn around and say it wouldnt, he said.

title: prevent tories launch review toxic
story: NewsPrevent: Tories launch review into toxic anti-terror scheme after long campaignLabour hailed the review after a campaign by the party and branded it "an acceptance that many have lost faith in Prevent"ShareCommentsByAlexander Britton:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsPrevent, which is aimed at all forms of extremism, has repeatedly come under fire, with critics labelling it heavy-handed and toxic "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThePreventanti-terrorscheme will undergo an independent review after concerns have previously been raised about the strategy. In announcing the move, security minister Ben Wallace said critics ofPreventhave previously used distortion and spin and urged them to produce solid evidence of their allegations. Prevent, which is aimed at all forms of extremism, has repeatedly come under fire, with critics labelling it heavy-handed and toxic. It is one strand of the Governments multi-pronged national counter-terrorism programme, which is known as Contest and dates back to , and provides support at an early stage to ert at-risk iniduals away fromterrorism.Labour said the review came after a long-running campaign by the party.Nick Thomas-Symonds, Shadow Minister for Security, said: This review is surely an acceptance that many have lost faith in Prevent.   Various communities, academics and senior officials have all criticised the government for its poor implementation of the strategy. “The aims of safeguarding, gathering information, and community cohesion have not always sat easily together. Nor can we expect local services, continually cut back by Tory austerity, to deliver the welfare community facilities we need without appropriate funding. It is now crucial that this review is wide-ranging and robust.” Security minister Ben Wallace said: I have decided that the time is now right to initiate a review ofPrevent. Communities across the country have got behind the policy and are contributing to it because they want, as we do, their own young people to be protected from grooming and exploitation byterrorists.  Over the last two years the Home Office has built on the solid work ofPreventby releasing annual statistics. They clearly show thatPreventis not about singling out any particular group or ideology but is similar to other forms of safeguarding, carried out every day by social workers, teachers and police. The Muslim Council of Britain welcomed the review, with secretary general Harun Khan saying: For far too long, thePreventstrategy has affected the lives of innocent families, been criticised for mainstreaming discrimination and lost the trust of communities around the UK. We welcome the Governments support for a review however those tasked with its implementation must have the independence, credibility and trust required to deliver it.

title: reality hard brexit mirror politics
story: NewsopinionThe reality of a hard Brexit: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe case against a harder Brexit has never been stronger but support for leaving the EU without a deal is hardening. This is why:ShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  JAN NewsopinionA hard Brexit would mean long queues at major ports "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email What does a politician do when the public stops listening  For opponents of Brexit this must be a frustrating time. Support for a no deal is becoming more entrenched at a time when the dangers of a no deal are becoming more apparent. There is no shortage of evidenceto reinforce the case against our leaving without a deal. When major firms such as Sony move their HQs overseas it means less money for the Treasury coffers which means less money for public services. . Senior civil servants warn they are unprepared for a no deal , thousands of ferry bookings and flights would be cancelled , medicines could be rationed and food supplies derailed. If we fall back on World Trade Organisation terms all our existing trade deals, including those signed as a member of the EU, cease to exist. This means the EU will want to check what goods are being imported and exported from the UK. Most modern manufacturers rely on just-in-time delivery for components. For example, the Nissan factory in Sunderland receives thousands of components a day.Some of these travel back and forth across the channel before final assembly. Any delay at the border adds to the company’s cost. Jaguar Land Rover has said a no deal would cost the company more than poundbn a year. Under WTO terms we would have to pay tarfs on exports to the EU, our largest trading partner. For cars this would be %, diary products up to % and some livestock as much as %. Remainers would have hoped this grim reality would have slain the Brexit dream. Instead apoll this week showed the most popular option on what we should do next is leave without a deal , followed by holding a second referendum . A separate poll for UK in a Changing Europe  found that % still believe the claim the UK sends poundmillion a weekto the EU even though this figure has been labelled a “misuse of statistics” by the UK Statistics Authority. UK in a Changing Europe also found that only % of leave votes believe a no deal Brexit will lead to a shortage of medicines.

title: chair covered pigeon poo sat
story: NewsChair covered in pigeon poo sat outside hospital for THREE months despite deathsTwo deaths at Queen Elizabeth University Hospital have been linked to bird faecesShareCommentsByVivienne Aitken:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe chair was spotted in the same position outside the hospital three months apart "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA chair covered in pigeon droppings sat in a car park outside a hospital for three months despite two deaths linked to bird faeces there. The pink chair was spotted in an alcove was seen in an alcove at the rear of the old neurological building at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. The tatty piece of furniture was pictured by a concerned patient in October, however, he didnt flag it to hospital bosses after bad news about his health. However, he got in touch with the Daily Record who then discovered the chair in the same position and still covered in pigeon excrement. The papers photographer noticed a walkway, which links the old building to the new, was also covered in pigeon droppings.   The patient, who does not wish to be identied because he is still receiving treatment at the hospital, said: “I was running late for my appointment in October, so I parked in the wee car park at the back of the neurological building because it was nearer the clinic. “I noticed the chair as I got out the car but because I was rushing to my appointment, I waited to take the picture when I came back out. “I knew when I saw it that it shouldn’t be there, especially in hospital grounds. The whole area was pretty much covered in it. “It seemed the area was getting used a lot because it was covered in cigarette butts. The main pathway was clear but the alcove was horrible.   “I know people shouldn’t be smoking in hospital grounds but they do andthey are standing there, they are coming into contact with it then taking it back into the hospital.” Last night, Labour’s health spokeswoman Monica Lennon said: “This is a shocking revelation about the extent of the apparent pigeon infestation at the Queen Elizabeth and it throws into serious doubt Jeane Freeman’s assertion that she has full confidence that all possible steps have been taken to prevent the spread of this infection. “A sick child dying in hospital as the result of an infection they have contracted is as serious as it gets. My thoughts remain with the loved ones of the patients involved and I urge the Health Secretary to take urgent action.” A spokesman for Greater Glasgow and Clyde Health Board said: “We recognise there are a number of pigeons around the hospital site and we have taken measures including netting and spikes to help reduce this issue. “Our facilities staff will continue to use pest control measures to reduce the presence of pigeons and we are consulting with pest control experts to seek other methods of control.”

title: chris packham says pets can
story: NewsChris Packham says pets can be as good as any partner - but his girlfriend disagreesThe Springwatch presenter and his other half talk animal companionshipShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  JAN NewsChris Packham is devoted to his dog, Scratchy"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAuthor Jilly Cooper is famous for writing about raunchy romantic relationships – but she now prefers her pet to any lover. Jilly, , was married to beloved husband Leo for  years until he died in , and says she doesn’t need to wed again because she has her greyhound, Bluebell. She said this week: “Instead of getting married again, one ought to get a dog. I talk to Bluebell all the time.” Another couple who are head over heels for their animals are Chris Packham, , and his partner of  years Charlotte Corney, . The Springwatch presenter, who has Asperger’s, is more comfortable with animals than people and is devoted to his poodle, Scratchy.He was devastated in , when Scratchy’s brother, Itchy, died.   Charlotte is equally passionate about animals, particularly the tigers she cares for at her zoo on the Isle of Wight, and her two pet giant rabbits, Otto and Abella. So we asked the nature-loving couple – can a pet really be as good as a partner  Yes, animals can be as good as a partner, writes Chris Charlotte is well aware that Scratchy, my -year-old poodle, is the epicentre of my universe. I’m wholly and totally devoted to him – he is the apple of my eye and singularly the most important organism to me on planet Earth, with no ambiguity about it at all. My love for him is immeasurable, and vice versa. I’ve just had to drop him off at his dog carers and he’s never happy when I leave him. He is with me all of the time at the moment. He’s about to have a cataract operation, which is going to be transformational. That’s been dficult, him not being able to see. But I am strangely excited about his operation – it will be successful and it will change his le. When Charlotte came along into the Chris-Itchy-Scratchy domain, she had to find her way into that trinity of two dogs and a man. But Charlotte loves Scratchy as well – greatly – and has accepted him. In terms of our relationship, it’s totally unconditional. When I get home he’s always pleased to see me and I am % pleased to see him. He is also totally dependent on me, whereas Charlotte isn’t. His health and well-being are something that I’m responsible for, which adds a dferent dimension to our relationship. Charlotte is independent. When you have a pet you have to take on the responsibility of looking after their health and well-being. I am totally devoted to him, but I need to be. He offers something that Charlotte can’t.   It’s that simple feeling of when I’m watching him bounding around in the woods, seeing him so happy and trying to imagine how he’s perceiving the world. It brings me so much joy. In many ways, the relationship I have with him is less complex but I think it’s more powerful. I wake up in the morning and I like to know that he’s there beside me. I love lying in bed just listening to him breathing and snoring – that closeness. I need that. I fret about him a lot when I’m away. People like me, with neurological dferences, we find it easier to form deep-rooted bonds with animals like that because we are not as good at understanding humans and our relationships with them. It’s something I’ve got better at over time – well, Charlotte might say otherwise. This morning I sent her a long email at .am about Scratchy and then she probably thinks, “My God, it’s . in the morning and he’s emailing me about the damn dog”. But one of the reasons Charlotte and I entertain a humanrelationship is because I know that she understands. She, to some extent, has that relationship with her big cats. So I am fortunate that Charlotte understands the gravity and depth of my relationship with Scratch. No, animals cant replace people, writes Charlotte   There are many benefits of a human partner over a pet. In my case, giant rabbits Otto and Abella. Partners don’t tend to vomit all over the bed, they don’t track mud into the house – well, most of the time – and you don’t have to worry about healthcare bills. You don’t need to be responsible for your partner’s fitness – Chris doesn’t need to be taken for walks. The rabbits can’t cook me dinner, which Chris sometimes does, and they can’t do my laundry. A big headache for us is going out for dinner with Scratchy. There’s still not much tolerance for having animals in restaurants, so romantic meals out are scarce. One of my favourite things over Christmas was spending time in London, just Chris and I, enjoying eating out and going to bars. It is very rare for us to be without our animals. While animals can communicate with us in many ways, they can’t talk back. Chris would probably argue he doesn’t need that much conversation, but he absolutely does need it.You can’t engage your pets in any problem-solving or have sophisticated dialogue to work out any logistical problems. Above all, pets have such a shorter lespan that we ultimately have to go through the heartache of losing them. But I cherish all the animals I’ve had. I completely know the position Scratchy holds in Chris’s le. There’s no competition there. Chris and I have found a way to make our lives revolve around our animals, but also each other. We wouldn’t have it any other way. The Wildheart Trust is raising money to bring two circus lions to the UK. To donate, visit justgiving campaign kumbaandvigo, or send a cheque to: The Wildheart Trust, Kumba and Vigo, Isle of Wight Zoo, Yaverland Rd, Yaverland, Sandown, PO QB.

title: inside britains worst street dubbed
story: NewsInside Britains worst street dubbed the Wild West where families live in fearResidents on Frances Road in Erdington, Birmingham have told of constant late night arguments, people being attacked and drugs being handed out like sweetsShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News EditorAshley Preece:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video inside-britains-worst-street-dubbed-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailResidents on Britains worst street - which has been dubbed the Wild West - have told of how they leave in fear and are afraid to leave their homes at night. Frances Road in Erdington, Birmingham, sees drugs being handed out like sweets while one victim was left bleeding after being attacked with a crowbar. Locals living in some of the  properties on the road say their living in constant fear and pictures and videos show the scale of the problem. The street is blighted by late-night fights and residents are extremely concerned about the level of drugs in the area. Footage even shows a man breathing and swallowing fire on the blighted street.   Erdington MP Jack Dromey admitted Frances Road has been plagued by issues and said residents shouldnt be fearful of leaving their homes at night.Speaking to Birmingham Live, he said: Ive met with residents of Frances Road and we are now planning to revisit the concerns, which have been ongoing for the last two years.Theres real concern and bitterness. For example, a woman purchased her great-grandfathers house which her family had lived in for many years. Its a glorious tall building but now, due to problems outside her front door, shes too frightened to go out at night and even live in it.   She shouldnt be feeling like this. Another example was when I spoke to a mum. Her daughter has to get the bus on Slade Road and shes too scared to walk down the street and says: Mum, can you come with me and walk me to the bus stop . Residents once living in a fine area say its changing beyond recognition and its partly down to the rapid growth of HMOs. Theres proof of bad landlords operating here, packing vulnerable tenants into squalid conditions to make money and, as a result, theres been a rapid growth of anti-social behaviour and crime. The police and the council need to be given the priority to tackle bad landlords head-on and punish those who are bringing down this fine community.  I will ensure no stone is left unturned. Bad landlords need to be named and shamed. The area has a number of HMOs- properties transformed by private landlords into six or seven-bedroom homes used to house strangers. Housing charities operate on Frances Road too and provide social housing for the most vulnerable. One resident says he witnesses drugs being given out like sweets on a daily basis and wants police officers to take the area more seriously. Wanting to remain anonymous, he said: [Frances Road] has been like this for years. Drugs are done openly in the middle of the day, people come down the road and give them out like sweets. The amount of drunks here as well is unbelievable. Theres road signs tied to lampposts warning of fines but people are just lying there passed out. You want to see the place in the summer.  Its just the sheer lack of police, theyre not physically coming out and looking at the problems. I understand the cutbacks but its frightening around here. House prices are cheap and landlords are buying the big houses, transforming them into seven-bedroom flats. These HMOs are gold mines and theyre becoming out of control. Its full of p*** heads and druggies but nothing ever gets done and were the ones having to live with it, day in day out. Stockland Green councillor Josh Jones said a public meeting was held with residents on Frances Road in August , with another taking place to discuss issues highlighted at the Highcroft Community Centre on September . [Frances Road] is a big problem, Coun Jones admitted. The cuts to police budgets isnt helping matters. For example, when I became councillor a few years ago there was double the people power in terms of police numbers. Landlords are just taking money, both in terms of registered providers and those who own the properties.  Housing in Stockland Green is cheap, hence HMOs are cropping up. Theres a real issue with drugs and drug dealing in particular. Its leading to petty crime and these people should be getting the support they need. The vulnerable victims are easy prey for dealers, its that simple. We need to stamp it out completely and Im working alongside my colleague councillor Penny Holbrook and Jack Dromey. Police are struggling. Those linked to drugs are stashing drugs where and people arent forthcoming to give out information because they feel scared.  Addressing the issue of HMOs in Birmingham Jim Crawshaw, head of private sector housing, said those seeking to transform properties into a house for multiple occupation now need a proper licence - and standards must always be met. He said: In October last year, the law changed which meant that an estimated additional , landlords in Birmingham now need an HMO licence. We are working with landlords to ensure that all properties that are renting property in this way, meet the standards and regulations expected of them. Where these standards are not met, enforcement action will be used.

story: NewsKate Middleton reveals what she finds hardest about being mum-of-threeDespite having a long-term live-in nanny and a housekeeper on hand to help with George, Charlotte and Louis, -year-old Kate said there are still times she feels the struggleShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video kate-middleton-listens-expert-coaching-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKate Middleton has opened up about the hardships of being a mum-of-three.Despite having a long-term live-in nanny and a housekeeper on hand to help with George, Charlotte and Louis, -year-old Kate said there are still times she feels the struggle as a parent. Speaking during a visit to charity Family Action, in Lewisham, South London, Kate said: Its so hard. You get a lot of support as a mother particularly in the early days, but after the age of one it falls away. After that there isnt a huge amount - lots of books to read. Everybody experiences the same struggle. The Duchess of Cambridge was at the charity to officially launch FamilyLine - a new telephone, text and email service which allows parents and carers to access support when they need help. Kate previously spoke about the huge challenges of motherhood while delivering a speech at the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists last year, reports the Mail.She said: Personally, becoming a mother has been such a rewarding and wonderful experience. However, at times it has also been a huge challenge - even for me who has support at home that most mothers do not. During yesterdays visit to the charity, Kate witnessed a role-playing training session for volunteers and staff. Sagari Sarkar, a volunteer who played a mum in need of support, said: I think it makes her human. It makes her in touch. She is a parent, a very active parent, and I think thats what people like about her.   The new charity helpline has been on a pilot trial for  months, before being launched nationwide. During her visit, the Duchess also met young people who are juggling school with caring for somebody at home. Praising them for their work, she said: You do an amazing job, I dont know how you do it.Yesterday, fashion fans were impressed by her sophisticated outfit choice, believed to be a modied version of a pound dress by Beulah London.As well as being a style hit, there is also a very important story behind the brand - and it is obvious why the Duchess has chosen to promote the company. It was set up by Lady Natasha Rufus Isaacs and Lavinia Brennan after they took part in a volunteer mission in Delhi in .   They met women who had been trafficked into the sex trade and saw first hand how their lives had been torn apart. So they decided to combine their love of fashion with their new passion for the cause, and set up their own luxury womenswear brand with a social conscience. Their website states: In  we embarked on a volunteer mission in Delhi, helping transform the lives of vulnerable women who had been trafficked into the sex trade against their will. It proved to be a mission that would transform our lives too.

title: mum dad turn diy detectives
story: NewsMum and dad turn DIY detectives in bid to clear son convicted of gang murderEXCLUSIVE: Michelle and Andrew Feather have always claimed their son is not guilty and now want to clear his nameShareCommentsByMatthew Young:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMichelle and Andrew Feather "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo parents have carried out DIY detective work to dig up evidence they believe could get their son’s murder conviction overturned. Andrew Feather, , is serving  years after being found guilty under the joint enterprise law of acting as a getaway driver in the killing of Barry Selby. But after months of work his mum Michelle and dad, also Andrew, have found possible discrepancies in CCTV times that were used to jail their boy. Their lawyers have now taken the evidence to the Criminal Cases Review Commission, which will considerit should be referred to the Court of Appeal.   Cleaner Michelle, , said: “We’ve always believed Andrew is not guilty. “I remember when he got found guilty and he was crying, and he looked at the judge and said, ‘You know I’m innocent – you know I’ve not done this’. “It’s on our mind  , from the moment we get up to the moment we go to bed, but we always want to look for more evidence.” Barry Selby, , was shot in the knee and doused with acid by a masked gang who burst into his bedroom in the early hours of October , . The dad-of-three later died in hospital.  Lee Calvert led the attack on Bradford’s East Bowling estate as an act of revenge related to a feud with Barry’s son Liam, the trial at the city’s crown court heard. Calvert, then aged , Joseph Lowther, , Robert Woodhead, , and Andrew Jnr were all convicted of murder in . But Andrew Jnr has always maintained his innocence, insisting he was two miles away on the Holme Wood estate, where he lived, at the time of the killing.  In convicting him, police gathered CCTV from dferent cameras to form a “presumed” route of a gold Vauxhall Astra that looked like his. But as the parents sted through the footage, Andrew Snr, , spotted shypotentially crucial evidence. Police used footage apparently showing Andrew Jnr’s car going past the Gold Shop, near the East Bowling estate, at .am.The same camera shows a distinctive poultry firm lorry going past at .am. Former trucker Andrew Snr knew the vehicle would have a tachograph – a device which monitors times and distances through GPS. He tracked down the firm and requested the data.   It showed the lorry had in fact driven past that camera between eight and  minutes before .am, and was likely to have been on the M at that time. Andrew Jnr’s defence team has argued this throws into question all of the police and prosecution’s CCTV timings, and means his car would actually have been filmed at about .am. A taxi driver who lived on the East Bowling estate said he drove into the area at .am and the Feathers believe this cabbie was mistaken for their son.Andrew Jnr was caught on CCTV earlier in the night on the Holme Wood estate and has insisted he never left. His parents say none of the estate cameras filmed him leaving. While the trial heard the four defendants were “friends”, Michelle insisted Andrew Jnr knew them only from growing up on the same estate and he “never went around with them”.  Simon Pook, of Robert Lizar Solicitors, helped to get Andrew Jnr’s original -year sentence reduced to  in . The firm is helping with background as a new team makes the fresh legal shychallenge. Mr Pook said: “The evidence, in my view, suggests Andrew Feather is shyinnocent. He was not part of this shyhorrendous murder. The getaway driver is still out there, in my view.” When they started investigating the crime, the Feathers “came in cold” with no experience. Michelle said: “We knew our son was innocent and the only thing we had to go at was the CCTV. It’s been hard work and we’re still not done, we’re still looking for anything  that could help.”  “When I got the news about the shytachograph reading, I was at work. “I was gobsmacked. It took us six months of late nights going through that footage, but it was worth it.” The parents visit their son once a month at HMP Gartree in Leicestershire. Andrew Jnr, who had a past conviction for dealing cannabis, is “getting on” with his sentence after a tough first two years. West Yorkshire Police said: “This matter is currently being reviewed by the CCRC and for that reason it would be inappropriate to comment any further.”

title: mum pregnant twins one rule
story: NewsMum pregnant with twins has one rule for babies birth - but not everyone agreesThe woman took to blog Mumsnet to ask for advice, but the opinions she received were idedShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe mum reached out to people on a blog"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother who is pregnant with twins has a simple rule for after the birth - but her request has ided opinions.The woman, writing on blog Mumsnet, said shes having twin girls after sadly losing a baby girl last January.Her babies are due next month, but she doesnt want any visitors for a whole month.She wants it to just be her, her husband, her two boys, and the twins together for the first four weeks.But the mum asked for peoples opinions as to whether it was fair to exclude extended family and friends.Some felt it was her choice to have whoever she wanted - or didnt want - present, but others disagreed.  The Mumsnet user LesMiracles wrote: im having twin girls i lost a baby girl in january last year. the twins are coming feb i dont want no visitors until  month from when they come i just want it to be my husband and my  boys plus my new babies for  month. my  boys i had visitors from day  all day all time and i just want it dferent this time. is that ok do u think. no grandparents they all dead but aunties and uncles and cousins and friends.   Some responses were supportive, saying it was her choice to do whatever she felt was right. One said: I thinkthat’s what feels right to you given your precious loss then it’s fine.You may find that when the babies are here you feel dferent but for now you need to make sure you do what is right for your mental health, especially after suffering a loss, with twin newborns.  Another agreed, saying: Its an exciting time, expecting your twins so soon. I can well understand you dont want visitors for a time.I didnt like having them very much, I wanted peace!But not everyone agreed, and some thought that it was unfair to exclude other family members who would want to be part of the birth. A user called cantchooseyourfamily said: Sorry to hear about your loss. I do think its unfair to extended family who I assume are excited about the arrival Could you not just be a bit stricter with times when you are free for visitors My children are still very young but I know I would be very upset to be banned from meeting future grandchildren for a month after their birth. Unless theres a massive backstory I thinks its OTT. Another suggested: Ultimately you set the rules but with twins you might appreciate some help. Writer of blog Dont Buy Her Flowers, Steph, posted about the concept of what her mum taught her was called pulling up the drawbridge.The idea is for mums to be kind to themselves after birth, and not feel any obligation to do anything.Steph said while you waddle and bleed, try to work out how to feed a baby and weep a bit as the hormones kick in, there are people sitting around drinking tea because they want to meet the baby practically as it’s coming out of you.She said its about getting the balance right, not cutting people out.It’s not about isolating yourself – on the days when I’ve got the energy, I get out and it feels glorious, Steph wrote.But by avoiding making too many plansI’ve avoided the anxiety I found those plans brought in the early weeks when I had Buster and Mabel.

title: mum shares picture raw kfc
story: NewsMum shares picture of raw KFC chicken as she slams staff for being very rudeThe woman, from Kingswood, Hull, was outraged by her meal but KFC insist the chicken wasnt undercookedShareByElaine McCahillAssistant News EditorSophie Corcoran:,  JAN NewsA mum has shared photos of disgusting chicken she was served at KFC in Kingswood, Hull "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA furious mum has shared pictures of raw chicken from KFC as she slated the outlets staff for being rude. The post, by the woman from Kingswood, Hull, went viral after she shared images of the red chicken in her snack box.She uploaded the pictures to Facebook and wrote: OMG from KFC at Kingswood u f****** watch your food.Her post has been shared more than , times with others agreeing that theyve had similar issues with the chain.  However, KFC as insisted the chicken wasnt undercooked but admitted it didnt look great.The woman told Hull Live: I have not been the first [to complain] and I dont think I will be the last. KFC are blind to this - my post is to warn people to look at their food.My husband did go back to the store and they said it was marinated not raw. I have gone to KFC and they have not replied, the only thing Ive heard is them saying they will get back within five days. The staff were very rude. People have commented and you can see how many people have had bad service and this is what needs to be put right.  Another woman commented: No way has it been marinated. Its not cooked you can see it just from the photo. You should have made the manager eat it there and then. One Facebook user said they had received disgraceful service. She said: Last time I went in was early last year and it was disgraceful it needs shutting down.  However, one person claimed they believed the redness was caused by the spices used on the chicken, which in turn stains the meat. They said: Its the spices they use it stains the meats. When lower quality chicken is used there tends to be blood within the bones which absorbs into the meat. Someone  said: Looks fine to me and looks cooked. The reason this happens is probably down to the youngness of the chickens they use.  Young chickens have thin and brittle bones and as such myoglobin leaks into the chicken and cartilage and looks red. Its fine. A KFC spokesman said: We know it doesnt look great, but this is actually a natural colouration caused by the bone, rather than being undercooked. This can sometimes happen when dealing with fresh chicken. Its not harmful but we are sorry for this womans experience and shes more than welcome to a free meal on us next time she visits.

title: mum two 20 left without
story: NewsMum-of-two, , left without heat or water for four days in sub-zero temperaturesShannon Avison and her two young sons, from Grimsby, had to share a bed and use an electric blanket to stay warm despite desperate calls to estate agents Ashton EstatesShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyConnor Lynch:,  JAN NewsShannon Avison had to sleep with her two sons on an electric blanket "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother-of-two was left without heating for days in biting sub-zero temperatures.Shannon Avison, , had no heating or hot water from Friday until yesterday and was forced to sleep in a bed with her two children on top of an electric blanket.The mum, from Grimsby, claimed she made a number of desperate calls to estate agents, Ashton Estates, asking them to fix the boiler.She says they told her they would send someone the same day - but was then left four days in freezing cold temperatures. Her parents had tried to get in contact with the estate agent over the weekend and Shannon said she was told a plumber would finally be round on Monday. As a result of having no heating or hot water, the mother said she was forced to go round to her parents house in order to wash her sons, two-year-old Azaan and nine-month old Sahil.   She also said she was forced to sleep three in a bed for four nights, while using an electric blanket in order to stay warm, because every room in the house was freezing. Shannon said: On Friday the boiler in my house started leaking and producing a strange burning smell, before it stopped working. I immediately rang Ashton Estates to ask them to come round and fix the boiler, as I have two very young sons who I cannot keep in a freezing house, and they told me that a plumber would be round to fix it. Come pm nobody had arrived, so I began to ring the emergency number. I tried numerous times to get through but was unable and eventually the phone itself was turned off.   Over the weekend I tried to ring them again, and so did my parents, with us leaving a lot of voicemails asking them to come and fix the boiler. However nobody got back to us at all. We were then told that a plumber would be round on Monday, but still nobody showed up. Because of this I was forced to look after my children in a freezing house, and the only source of heat that we had was a broken radiator that probably isnt safe and an electric blanket. It takes the radiator about five hours to heat a room and both items use a lot of electricity. My children had to wash at my parents house. I just wanted someone to come round and fix our boiler, I have two infant sons and they shouldnt have to live like this.   A spokesperson from Ashton Estates said a plumber visited the property on Tuesday and managed to get the boiler working again but said the reason it had not been working was due to no gas being on the meter, a claim refuted by Shannon. Ashton Estates said: Our plumbers are very busy but managed to get round earlier today and the gas is now back on. We found the issue to be that there was no gas on the meter, although the plumber did not actually look at the meter itself. They have said that a notication on the boiler indicated to them that there was no gas. Shannon said she did have gas in the meter for the whole weekend, and that the plumber had told her that there was an issue with steam in the boiler and that was what caused it to break.

title: six things you should not
story: NewsSix things you SHOULD NOT DO as temperatures across the UK plummetWe all know we should avoid unnecessary travel during snow fall but there are a few things you need to avoidShareCommentsByJenny KirkhamOliver Milne:,  JAN NewsThe extreme weather is causing misery for people across the country "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTemperatures across the UK have plummeted, with heavy snow and ice hitting parts of the country. As the country shivers, there are several things that you need to avoid doingyou want to minimise the impact of this weeks snowy spell. So we all know we should be avoiding all unnecessary travel during snow fall and taking extra care while out and about. But here some tips you might not know according to the Liverpool Echo .  DO NOT pour boiling water on your car windscreen Pouring hot water on your windscreen may seem like the quickest way to defrost it, especially in that early morning rush. But the rapid expansion and contraction of the ice as a result of the hot water could cause the screen to crack. Instead, turn on the engine and allow the air-conditioning to circulate around the car.  DO NOT leave your car unattended Owners who leave their engines running while they run inside to grab something they’ve forgotten are a car thief’s dream - and also breaking the law. Drivers have to be ‘in control’ of their vehicle at all times. If you need to go back into the house you should turn off the engine, lock the car and head in. Car insurers rarely pay outthe keys are left in the car.  DO NOT drive to normal road conditions Driving in snow and ice should not be taken for granted, no matter how little your area might have received. Black ice in particular has caused many accidents on roads where people thought they were clear to drive as normal. Leave plenty of time for all journeys and take extra time to get from A to B. Don’t forget to maintain safe stopping distances and use your fog lights accordingly. For more information on how to drive safely in the ice and snow click here  DO NOT neglect your health during cold spells The Met Office have provided a number of tips to keep people healthy while weather warnings for ice and snow are in place . Keep your hands and face warm -they get cold they can trigger a rise in blood pressure which puts you at increased risk of a heart attack. . Remember that several thin layers of clothing will keep you warmer than one thick layer, as the layers trap warm air. . Wear warm clothes in bed. When very cold, wear thermal underwear, bed socks and even a hat - a lot of heat is lost through your head.

story: NewsVictoria Pendleton reveals phone call that saved her le as she considered suicideThe double Olympic gold medallist has spoken candidly of her battle with severe depressionShareCommentsByToby Meyjes:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsVictoria Pendleton  celebrating Olympic success - has revealed how she spiralled into depression "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVictoria Pendleton has revealed she was on the brink of taking her own le as she battled severe depression. The double Olympic cycling gold medalist spoke bravely about how her le deteriorated last summer after she ed from a TV climb of Everest. She said had even worked out how to do it and fantasised about killing herself on a daily basis. At her lowest point, the -year-old revealed she woke up thinking I dont want to see tomorrow. She called former British Cycling psychiatrist Steve Peters and thinks his answer might have saved her le. Because I don’t think I would be herehe hadn’t.” She revealed how Peters kept her talking as he contacted her twin brother Alex who went to her house and took the pills. story: NewsMum breastfeeding twins at nursery told to move as its inappropriatePhotographer Jenner Mancuso, , from Ohio, USA, was left in disbelief and initially refused to back down - but she later received an apologyShareCommentsByAlyce Collins:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mother-ordered-breastfeed-twins-private-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum of four was told not to breastfeed her twins in the public space at their own NURSERY because it was deemed inappropriate and could offend religious beliefs. Jenner Mancuso claims she was forced to go to another room no bigger than a wardrobe to continue tandem feeding Aria and Asha, who are  months old. The -year-old from from Ohio, USA, was left in disbelief with neither her nor the staff member backing down.   Photographer Jenner eventually conceded defeat, but later that week the nursery manager apologised and even teared up. Jenner is speaking out about the incident, which happened in August , in the hope that by standing up for her rights she will help other mothers. She said: Its natural and frankly I dont caresomeone sees my breast, or a glimpse of my nipple doing what nature created it to do.  Jenner, who has four daughters Parker, four, Piper three, and twins Aria and Asher, as well as three step-children, Adriana, , Vegah, nine, and Copeland, seven, breastfed her two older girls until they weaned off, and is still nursing the twins. She was tandem breastfeeding Aria and Asher inside their nursery when an employee asked her to relocate to the staff room, a small and boxy room which couldnt be seen into.  Jenner was told that she had to nurse her daughters in a private space because some of the children were school-aged and it could be inappropriate for them to see. The director also felt that it was best for Jenner not to nurse in a public area of the centre in case she offended any religious beliefs of other parents. The staff at the day-care went back and forth with Jenner, telling her where she could and couldnt breastfeed. Jenner was close to removing her daughters from the centre until after three weeks of dispute, she received an apology from the director. Staff at the nursery reviewed their policies to make sure the same situation would never occur again.  Jenner has shared her experience to normalise breastfeeding so other mothers arent afraid of it. Both my twins were able to latch on right away, but I think it helped that I was a veteran at breastfeeding by then, so it didnt intimidate me, said Jenner. I nursed my first two in public, but I wasnt nearly as confident as I am with the twins. I would turn bright red and have beads of sweat drip down my face because I was so insecure and afraid that someone would say something negative to me. However, the more I did it in public, the more I realised that most people dont care, andthey do, they keep it to themselves.   Parker, my oldest, breastfed until  months, and Piper stopped at  months. Partially I think they self-weaned due to a change in the taste of my breastmilk from getting pregnant. I nurse the twins two to three times a day, buttheyre feeling unwell it may be more often than that. Its much more dficult to breastfeed discreetly when there are two. When the babies were very young and unable to support themselves, I had to latch them on myself and hold them there simultaneously. Because of my schedule with the older two, it works best for me to breastfeed the twins at drop-off and pick-up.   One morning I began nursing Asher on a chair before I left and the director said she needed me to nurse in the back, in the staff room, which is no bigger than a wardrobe. They told me that I wasnt allowed to nurse my babies in any of the public spaces because it had to be in a private space, because they have school-aged children. That implies what Im doing is inappropriate for older children to witness. The manager of the location chimed in and stated that it was also to protect other parents who may find it offensive due to religion. I literally scoffed out loud at her and shared it on my Instagram in disbelief. We went back and forth several times, but no one was backing down. I couldnt immediately withdraw them and seek new childcare, but they needed nursing.   So, I conceded and went to the break room. Later that week the manager apologised and even teared up. By the end of September, I spoke with the director who accepted that shed misunderstood the company policy regarding privacy. I told her that a misunderstanding like that is not acceptable. Later that evening I got a call from the director who was completely apologetic. She explained how sorry she was about her comments. She saw how negatively that could make a new or insecure breastfeeding mother feel and potentially ruin a journey. She said theyd update their handbook to make it clear so there is no more confusion. She also askedI would be open to providing additional documents or insight, and of course I agreed.   Over the years Jenner has become confident about nursing in public and she knew her rights, so she explained to the staff that although their comments angered her deeply, they didnt stop her breastfeeding. However, the same might not have been saidthey treated a new mum who was less confident nursing in the same way. I am majorly pro-breastfeeding in public because thats the only way it will ever become normalised, said Jenner. I could have stormed off and immediately put my kids in a dferent school, but I didnt. I saw a teaching opportunity. Isnt that what normalising is all about - spreading awareness    Breastfeeding is important on so many dferent levels for me. There are benefits that my babies receive from my breastmilk and there are so many health benefits that I also receive from breastfeeding, including reduced rates of multiple dferent types of cancer. Im also very passionate about normalising it because I want to help other mums have the strength to see it through and not be afraid to breastfeed in public. You can follow Jenners breastfeeding journey by visiting @jenner.mancuso where she hopes to inspire other mothers across the world.
